L1.brief_rationale: The broadest term for the discipline itself; universally recognized as the love of wisdom and the systematic study of fundamental questions.
The most fundamental epistemological concept; universally understood as justified true belief or acquaintance with facts.
A concept central to all branches of philosophy; universally recognized as correspondence between statements and reality.
The capacity for rational thought that defines philosophical inquiry itself; universally familiar from everyday discourse.
The central concept of aesthetics; universally recognized as an attribute of things that provides pleasure or satisfaction to the senses or mind.
The quality that philosophy literally pursues (philo-sophia); universally understood as deep understanding and good judgment.
The most widely recognized philosophical question; familiar to virtually everyone regardless of educational background.
A concept central to political philosophy and existentialism; universally understood as the absence of constraint or the capacity for self-determination.
The medium of thought and communication whose nature is examined across philosophy of language, hermeneutics, and phenomenology; universally familiar.
The systematic enterprise whose methods, assumptions, and limits are examined by philosophy of science; universally recognized.
The domain of belief in the divine and sacred, whose claims are examined by philosophy of religion; universally familiar across cultures.
Human creative expression whose nature, value, and definition are central questions of aesthetics; universally recognized.
A universal human aspiration examined philosophically from Aristotle's eudaimonia to modern well-being research; understood by all.

L2.brief_rationale: The branch of philosophy studying knowledge, justification, and belief; one of the first sub-fields encountered by philosophy students.
The branch of philosophy dealing with the nature of beauty, art, and taste; standard content in introductory philosophy courses.
The examination of scientific methods, assumptions, and implications; a well-known sub-field taught in undergraduate programs.
The philosophical study of government, justice, rights, liberty, and law; widely taught and historically central to the discipline.
The study of meaning, reference, and the relationship between language and reality; a core analytic philosophy sub-field taught in undergraduate curricula.
The philosophical movement emphasizing individual existence, freedom, and choice; widely recognized through Sartre, Camus, and Kierkegaard.
The rational examination of religious concepts including God's existence, the problem of evil, and faith; a standard undergraduate offering.
The epistemological view that knowledge derives from sensory experience; associated with Locke, Berkeley, and Hume, taught in every history of philosophy course.
The epistemological view that knowledge can be gained through reason alone; associated with Descartes, Spinoza, and Leibniz, a standard introductory topic.
The philosophical position questioning the possibility of certain knowledge; from ancient Pyrrhonism to Descartes's method of doubt, a foundational topic.
Husserl's method of studying structures of experience and consciousness from the first-person perspective; a major tradition in continental philosophy.
The American philosophical tradition linking meaning and truth to practical consequences; associated with Peirce, James, and Dewey.
The dialectical method of inquiry through systematic questioning attributed to Socrates; widely known as a foundational philosophical technique.

L3.brief_rationale: The study of the nature, direction, and meaning of historical processes; requires familiarity with Hegel, Marx, and analytic philosophy of historiography.
The theory of interpretation originating in biblical exegesis, developed by Schleiermacher, Dilthey, Gadamer, and Ricoeur into a general philosophical method.
Popper's criterion that scientific theories must be capable of being shown false; a central concept in philosophy of science requiring understanding of demarcation.
Kuhn's concept that scientific revolutions involve wholesale replacement of theoretical frameworks rather than incremental progress; requires knowledge of The Structure of Scientific Revolutions.
Austin and Searle's framework analyzing how utterances perform actions (promising, commanding, asserting); requires working knowledge of locutionary, illocutionary, and perlocutionary acts.
The demonstration that justified true belief is insufficient for knowledge; a pivotal challenge in epistemology requiring familiarity with the classical analysis of knowledge.
The argument that the existence of suffering is incompatible with an omnipotent, omniscient, benevolent God; requires engagement with theodicies and logical vs. evidential formulations.
The view that knowledge rests on basic, self-justifying beliefs; requires understanding of the regress problem and its alternatives (coherentism, infinitism).
Rawls's thought experiment in which rational agents behind a veil of ignorance choose principles of justice; requires working familiarity with A Theory of Justice.
Derrida's strategy of reading texts to expose internal contradictions and assumptions about meaning; requires working knowledge of post-structuralist philosophy.
The aesthetic experience of awe and overwhelm before vast or powerful phenomena; requires understanding of Burke's and Kant's differing treatments.
The epistemological view that a belief is justified if produced by a reliable cognitive process; requires understanding of externalist vs. internalist justification debates.

L4.brief_rationale: The thesis that empirical evidence alone cannot determine which scientific theory is correct; requires deep engagement with Quine and Duhem on holism and theory choice.
Kripke's concept that proper names refer to the same object in all possible worlds; requires expert-level knowledge of Naming and Necessity and its anti-descriptivist arguments.
Quine's criterion that one is committed to the entities over which one's best theory quantifies; requires expert familiarity with 'On What There Is' and the indispensability argument.
Fricker's framework analyzing how prejudice can wrong someone specifically in their capacity as a knower; requires deep knowledge of testimonial and hermeneutical injustice.

The family of views holding that 'is true' adds no substantive property to a proposition and serves merely a logical or expressive function; requires expert-level engagement with Tarski, Quine, and Horwich.
Gadamer's concept that understanding arises when the interpreter's and text's historical horizons merge; requires deep knowledge of Truth and Method and philosophical hermeneutics.
Rawls's requirement that political justification in a liberal democracy appeal only to reasons acceptable to all reasonable citizens; requires expert engagement with Political Liberalism.
The formal framework modeling rational belief updating via Bayes' theorem; requires deep knowledge of probability calculus, Dutch book arguments, and conditionalization.

The debate over whether scientific theories describe mind-independent reality or are merely empirically adequate instruments; requires expert engagement with the no-miracles argument and pessimistic meta-induction.
Husserl's technical distinction between the act of consciousness (noesis) and its intended object (noema); requires deep expertise in Ideas I and the phenomenological reduction.
The view that knowledge attributions are sensitive to the conversational context of the attributor; requires expert familiarity with DeRose, Lewis, and the debate over skeptical scenarios.

Habermas's theory that rationality is grounded in the norms implicit in communicative action oriented toward mutual understanding; requires deep knowledge of The Theory of Communicative Action and discourse ethics.
